expanded_description: The long-run Phillips curve is one of the most important concepts in macroeconomics. It embodies the idea that there is no permanent tradeoff between inflation and unemployment - that in the long run, unemployment returns to its natural rate regardless of the inflation rate. This vertical curve represents the limits of monetary policy: central banks can influence inflation, but they cannot permanently reduce unemployment below its natural rate. Understanding this concept is essential for grasping modern monetary policy, the costs of inflation, and why central banks focus on price stability.

core_concept.principle: The long-run Phillips curve is vertical at the natural rate of unemployment. This means that in the long run, there is no tradeoff between inflation and unemployment. Regardless of the inflation rate, unemployment will return to its natural rate, determined by real factors like labor market structure, technology, and demographics. Monetary policy cannot permanently affect unemployment; it can only influence inflation.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine a rubber band. In the short run, you can stretch it - that's like pushing unemployment below the natural rate with expansionary policy. But when you let go, it snaps back. The long-run Phillips curve is like the rubber band's natural length. No matter how hard you pull, it always returns to that length. Similarly, no matter how much the central bank tries to stimulate the economy, unemployment will eventually return to its natural rate. The only lasting effect is higher inflation. This insight, developed by Milton Friedman and Edmund Phelps, revolutionized macroeconomics. It means that central banks can't create permanent prosperity by printing money - they can only create inflation. Their proper role is to maintain price stability and let real factors determine employment.

image.caption: The long-run Phillips curve is vertical at the natural rate. Short-run curves shift with expected inflation, but the long-run relationship is vertical.

sections.introduction: In the 1960s, many economists believed there was a permanent tradeoff between inflation and unemployment. They thought policy makers could choose any point on the Phillips curve - a little more inflation for a little less unemployment. Then Milton Friedman and Edmund Phelps showed why this couldn't be true. In the long run, they argued, the Phillips curve is vertical. There is no permanent tradeoff. This insight transformed how we think about monetary policy and remains central to macroeconomics today.

key_concept.definition: The long-run Phillips curve (LRPC) is a vertical line at the natural rate of unemployment $U_n$. It shows that in the long run, unemployment is independent of the inflation rate. The curve is vertical because expectations adjust fully to actual inflation over time. Any attempt to maintain unemployment below $U_n$ will only cause ever-accelerating inflation as expectations rise. The LRPC embodies the natural rate hypothesis: the economy tends to return to its natural rate regardless of monetary policy.
key_concept.context: The concept of a vertical long-run Phillips curve was developed independently by Milton Friedman and Edmund Phelps in the late 1960s. They argued that the apparent Phillips curve tradeoff was only temporary because it depended on inflation expectations. In the long run, expectations catch up, and the only sustainable unemployment rate is the natural rate. This idea was dramatically confirmed in the 1970s when both inflation and unemployment rose together - something the simple Phillips curve couldn't explain. The natural rate hypothesis is now a cornerstone of macroeconomics, guiding central banks to focus on price stability rather than trying to permanently reduce unemployment. It also explains why the costs of reducing inflation can be high: when expectations are unanchored, disinflation requires a period of high unemployment to bring them back down.

categories.description: The long-run curve is derived from the expectations-augmented Phillips curve when expectations fully adjust.

examples.explanation: The short-run Phillips curve is $\pi = \pi^e - \beta(U - U_n) + \epsilon$. In the long run, expectations adjust so that $\pi^e = \pi$ (people correctly anticipate inflation). Assuming no supply shocks ($\epsilon = 0$), the equation becomes $\pi = \pi - \beta(U - U_n)$, which simplifies to $\beta(U - U_n) = 0$, so $U = U_n$. Unemployment equals the natural rate regardless of inflation.
This means the long-run Phillips curve is a vertical line at $U = U_n$. No matter what the inflation rate is, unemployment returns to its natural level.

The key insight is that expectations adjust. If the central bank tries to keep unemployment below $U_n$, inflation rises. Once people expect that higher inflation, the short-run curve shifts up, and unemployment returns to $U_n$ at the new, higher inflation rate.

categories.description: The hypothesis that the economy tends to return to its natural rate regardless of monetary policy.

examples.explanation: The natural rate hypothesis says that there is no long-run tradeoff between inflation and unemployment. The economy's average unemployment rate is determined by real factors - labor market structure, technology, demographics - not by monetary policy. Monetary policy can only influence inflation in the long run.

This means central banks cannot permanently reduce unemployment by printing money. They can temporarily boost employment at the cost of higher inflation, but eventually unemployment returns to its natural rate. Their proper role is to maintain price stability.

The 1970s provided dramatic evidence. Countries that tried to maintain low unemployment through expansionary policy ended up with high inflation but no permanent reduction in unemployment. The natural rate hypothesis has held up well empirically.

categories.type: Shifts in the Long-Run Phillips Curve
categories.description: While the LRPC is vertical, it can shift over time as the natural rate itself changes.

examples.process: Factors that shift the natural rate
examples.explanation: The natural rate changes with demographics, technology, labor market institutions, and policy. For example, the entry of baby boomers and women into the labor force in the 1970s may have raised the natural rate. Improved job matching technology (like online job sites) may have lowered it.

A change in the natural rate shifts the entire vertical LRPC left or right. If the natural rate falls from 5% to 4%, the LRPC shifts left. The economy can sustain lower unemployment without accelerating inflation.

This means that while monetary policy can't permanently change unemployment, other policies can. Education, training, labor market reforms, and policies that affect labor supply and demand can shift the natural rate. This is why supply-side policies matter.

categories.description: Bringing inflation down when expectations are high requires a temporary period of high unemployment - the sacrifice ratio.

examples.explanation: If inflation expectations are high, reducing inflation requires a period of unemployment above the natural rate. The sacrifice ratio measures the cumulative loss of output (or years of excess unemployment) needed to reduce inflation by 1 percentage point.
If the central bank has credibility, expectations may adjust faster, reducing the sacrifice ratio. This is why central banks work to build credibility - it makes disinflation less costly.

In the early 1980s, Fed Chair Paul Volcker reduced inflation from about 10% to about 3%. The cost was a severe recession with unemployment peaking at 10.8%. The sacrifice ratio was substantial, but it established Fed credibility and led to decades of low inflation.

principles.principle: The Long-Run Phillips Curve Is Vertical at the Natural Rate
principles.statement: In the long run, there is no relationship between inflation and unemployment. The economy's average unemployment rate is determined by real factors, not by monetary policy. The long-run Phillips curve is a vertical line at the natural rate of unemployment.
principles.application: This principle sets the fundamental limit on monetary policy. Central banks cannot permanently reduce unemployment below the natural rate. Attempts to do so will only cause ever-accelerating inflation. This is why modern central banks focus on price stability rather than employment targets beyond the short run.
principles.example: In the 1960s, many believed a 4% unemployment rate was sustainable. Policy makers pursued expansionary policies to achieve this. Initially, unemployment fell to 3.5% and inflation rose modestly. But by the 1970s, inflation expectations had adjusted, and unemployment returned to its natural rate (estimated at 6%) while inflation remained high. The attempt to permanently beat the natural rate failed.

principles.principle: Only Real Factors Determine the Natural Rate in the Long Run
principles.statement: The natural rate of unemployment is determined by structural features of the economy: demographics, technology, labor market institutions (unemployment insurance, minimum wage, union power), education and training systems, and the pace of structural change. Monetary policy cannot affect these factors.
principles.application: This principle guides policy makers to distinguish between cyclical and structural unemployment. If unemployment is high due to cyclical factors, monetary policy can help. If it's high due to structural factors, other policies - education, training, labor market reforms - are needed. Monetary policy alone cannot solve structural problems.
principles.example: In Europe in the 1990s and 2000s, many countries had persistently high unemployment despite low inflation. This suggested a high natural rate, likely due to labor market rigidities, generous unemployment benefits, and other structural factors. Policy makers focused on labor market reforms rather than monetary stimulus.

principles.principle: Expectations Adjustment Makes the Long-Run Curve Vertical
principles.statement: The long-run Phillips curve is vertical because inflation expectations eventually adjust to actual inflation. If the central bank tries to keep unemployment below the natural rate, inflation rises. Once people expect higher inflation, the short-run curve shifts up, and unemployment returns to the natural rate at the new, higher inflation level.
principles.application: This principle explains why inflation can accelerate. If the central bank persists in keeping unemployment below the natural rate, expectations will keep adjusting upward, leading to ever-higher inflation. This is why the natural rate is sometimes called the NAIRU (Non-Accelerating Inflation Rate of Unemployment).
principles.example: In the late 1960s and 1970s, the Fed tried to maintain low unemployment. Each time inflation rose, they initially succeeded, but expectations caught up, requiring even higher inflation to keep unemployment down. This created an accelerating spiral that ended only when the Fed under Volcker broke expectations by causing a severe recession.

principles.principle: Disinflation Has Real Costs When Expectations Are Unanchored
principles.statement: If inflation expectations are high and unanchored, reducing inflation requires a period of unemployment above the natural rate. The sacrifice ratio measures these costs. The more credible the central bank, the lower the sacrifice ratio, because expectations adjust faster.
principles.application: This principle explains why central banks work so hard to maintain credibility. A credible central bank can reduce inflation with less economic pain because people adjust their expectations quickly. This is also why central banks communicate clearly about their goals and actions.
principles.example: When the Bank of England gained operational independence in 1997 and adopted an inflation target, it built credibility. When inflation rose in the 2000s, they could raise rates without causing a major recession because markets believed they would follow through. This contrasts with the 1970s, when the Fed lacked credibility and had to cause a deep recession to bring inflation down.

worked_examples.title: Deriving the Long-Run Phillips Curve
worked_examples.problem: The short-run Phillips curve for an economy is given by $\pi = \pi^e - 0.4(U - 5)$. The natural rate of unemployment is 5%. a) If expected inflation is 2%, what is the short-run relationship? b) In the long run, expectations adjust so that $\pi^e = \pi$. What unemployment rate results? c) What does this imply about the long-run Phillips curve? d) If the natural rate falls to 4%, what happens to the long-run curve?

step_by_step.explanation: In the long run, $\pi^e = \pi$. Substitute into the equation: $\pi = \pi - 0.4(U - 5)$. This simplifies to $0 = -0.4(U - 5)$, so $U - 5 = 0$, thus $U = 5$.
Regardless of the inflation rate, unemployment equals 5% in the long run. The long-run Phillips curve is vertical at U = 5%.

If the natural rate falls to 4%, the long-run Phillips curve shifts left to a vertical line at U = 4%. The economy can now sustain lower unemployment without accelerating inflation. This would happen if, for example, labor market efficiency improved or demographics changed.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Short-run: $\pi = 4 - 0.4U$. b) Long-run unemployment = 5%. c) LRPC is vertical at 5%. d) LRPC shifts left to vertical at 4%.
worked_examples.concept_applied: The long-run Phillips curve is derived from the short-run curve by setting expected inflation equal to actual inflation. It is vertical at the natural rate, which can shift over time due to real factors.

worked_examples.title: The Cost of Disinflation
worked_examples.problem: An economy has expected inflation of 8% and a natural rate of 5%. The Phillips curve is $\pi = \pi^e - 0.5(U - 5)$. The central bank wants to reduce inflation to 2% permanently. a) If expectations are slow to adjust and remain at 8% initially, what unemployment rate is needed to achieve 2% inflation in the short run? b) If the adjustment takes 3 years, with unemployment at that level, what is the cumulative unemployment above the natural rate? c) If each 1 percentage point of excess unemployment for one year reduces inflation by 0.5 percentage points (as in the Phillips curve), what is the sacrifice ratio (cumulative excess unemployment needed to reduce inflation by 1 point)? d) How would credibility affect this?

step_by_step.step: Calculate unemployment needed with fixed expectations
step_by_step.explanation: With $\pi^e = 8$, target $\pi = 2$: $2 = 8 - 0.5(U - 5)$ → $0.5(U - 5) = 6$ → $U - 5 = 12$ → $U = 17\%$. This is a severe recession.
Excess unemployment = $U - U_n = 17 - 5 = 12$ percentage points per year. Over 3 years, cumulative excess = $12 \times 3 = 36$ percentage point-years.

Inflation reduction = $8 - 2 = 6$ percentage points. Sacrifice ratio = cumulative excess unemployment / inflation reduction = $36 / 6 = 6$. This means it takes 6 percentage point-years of excess unemployment to reduce inflation by 1 percentage point.

If the central bank has credibility, expectations might adjust faster. For example, if expectations fell to 4% after one year, the required unemployment would be lower in subsequent years. The sacrifice ratio would be smaller. This is why credibility matters - it reduces the cost of disinflation.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Unemployment needed = 17%. b) Cumulative excess = 36 percentage point-years. c) Sacrifice ratio = 6. d) Credibility reduces the sacrifice ratio by speeding up expectations adjustment.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Disinflation has real costs when expectations are unanchored. The sacrifice ratio measures these costs. Central bank credibility can reduce the sacrifice ratio by speeding up expectations adjustment.

worked_examples.title: Shifts in the Natural Rate
worked_examples.problem: In 1980, an economy had a natural rate estimated at 6%. By 2000, after improvements in job matching technology, increased labor market flexibility, and demographic changes, the natural rate fell to 4.5%. a) What happens to the long-run Phillips curve? b) If the central bank had been targeting 5% unemployment in 1980, would that have been below or above the natural rate? What would have happened to inflation? c) In 2000, can the economy sustain 5% unemployment without accelerating inflation? d) What does this illustrate about the relationship between policy and the natural rate?

step_by_step.explanation: The long-run Phillips curve shifts left from a vertical line at 6% to a vertical line at 4.5%. The economy can now sustain lower unemployment without inflationary pressure.

In 1980, 5% unemployment was below the natural rate (6%). This would have created inflationary pressure. Over time, inflation would rise, and unemployment would return to 6% at a higher inflation rate.

In 2000, 5% unemployment is above the natural rate (4.5%). Actually 5% > 4.5%, so 5% is above the natural rate? Wait careful: 5% > 4.5%, so 5% is above the natural rate. That means there is slack - unemployment is higher than the natural rate, so inflation should fall. So 5% is actually above the natural rate in 2000, meaning the economy could sustain even lower unemployment (down to 4.5%) without inflation.

This illustrates that the same unemployment rate can have very different implications depending on the natural rate. In 1980, 5% was inflationary; in 2000, 5% was actually contractionary (would lead to falling inflation). Policy makers must have good estimates of the natural rate to interpret current conditions correctly.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) LRPC shifts left from 6% to 4.5%. b) In 1980, 5% was below natural rate, causing rising inflation. c) In 2000, 5% is above natural rate (4.5%), so inflation would fall - the economy could sustain even lower unemployment. d) The same numerical unemployment rate can mean different things as the natural rate changes.
worked_examples.concept_applied: The natural rate changes over time due to real factors. This means policy makers must continuously update their estimates. What looks like low unemployment in one era might be high in another relative to the natural rate.

image.alt: Graph showing the long-run Phillips curve shifting left as the natural rate falls due to improved labor market efficiency, demographics, and technology
image.caption: The long-run Phillips curve shifts when the natural rate changes due to real economic factors.

summary: The long-run Phillips curve is vertical at the natural rate of unemployment, embodying the natural rate hypothesis that there is no permanent tradeoff between inflation and unemployment. This curve is derived from the expectations-augmented Phillips curve by setting expected inflation equal to actual inflation: when $\pi^e = \pi$, the equation $\pi = \pi^e - \beta(U - U_n)$ simplifies to $U = U_n$. Regardless of the inflation rate, unemployment returns to its natural rate in the long run. This means that monetary policy cannot permanently reduce unemployment below the natural rate. Attempts to do so will only lead to ever-accelerating inflation as expectations adjust upward. The natural rate itself is determined by real factors: demographics (age structure of the population), labor market institutions (unemployment insurance, minimum wage laws, union power), technology (job matching efficiency, skill requirements), education and training systems, and structural changes in the economy. While monetary policy cannot affect the natural rate, other policies can. Education and training, labor market reforms, infrastructure investment, and policies that affect labor supply and demand can shift the natural rate over time. The long-run Phillips curve shifts left or right as the natural rate changes. The concept has important implications for disinflation. If inflation expectations are high and unanchored, reducing inflation requires a temporary period of unemployment above the natural rate. The sacrifice ratio measures the cumulative excess unemployment (or lost output) needed to reduce inflation by 1 percentage point. Central bank credibility can reduce the sacrifice ratio by speeding up expectations adjustment. The long-run Phillips curve is a cornerstone of modern macroeconomics. It explains why the 1970s stagflation occurred, why central banks focus on price stability, and why monetary policy cannot create permanent prosperity. It also highlights the importance of supply-side policies for improving long-run economic performance.
